content.body: hm, is aside the correct element to use to mark up parentheticals, even if those parentheticals should be |display: inline|?
jwalden: no, use Unicode characters U+0028 and U+0029 to mark up parentheticals.
anyone got any opinions on bruce's e-mail regarding whether to use <figure> or <aside> for pullquotes?
i guess <aside> is better
Hixie: thanks; might be worth adding an informative sentence to <aside> mentioning that anti-use case
added a comment, dunno if it'll confuse more than it helps, though
looks
waits for http://html5.org/tools/web-apps-tracker (presumably) to pick up the change
reads the parts of the ffmpeg/chrome thread he hadn't read yet, merely seen as having happened, and is bemused at how quickly things went south when some people chose not to shut up
frankly, I'm amazed it took so long to catch flame :-D
so predictable: http://twitter.com/jdowdell/status/2085821360
HTML5 fully speciying something and being silent on whether it is conforming or not seems difficult
Unless HTML5 made no claims about document conformance at all, I suppose
But that seems... unhelpful
"To call out just one change, note that Snow Leopard now defaults to the same display gamma as Windows — 2.2 instead of 1.8." does this mean PNG now works the same everywhere?
<di> ftw
annevk42: I don't think so
(the png thing)
(at least I think that change alone doesn't solve the problem that hsivonen always brings up which is that png colours may not match CSS colours in browsers that have support for PNG colour profiles)
http://hsivonen.iki.fi/png-gamma/ suggests it is about gamma
it seems it was not much of a problem anyway anymore
annevk42: I don't understand this much but there is also the colour space issue
Oh wait, I am thinking about JPEGs although the same applies to PNG afaik
when browsers do ICC stuff, you can now enjoy the old png-gamma problem with JPEGs, too!
annevk42: the main old problem was that some old browsers didn't make PNG color "management" opt-in
hsivonen: For JPEGs it makes much more sense since fewer people are using JPEGs as part of their site design
w00t! finally gamma sanity at Apple with the 2.2 default.
time to party. at last!
reads logs backwards
existing content and degrading gracefully FTW!
Mac-created content degrading gracefully on Windows, that is
and existing Windows-created content working on Mac
hsivonen, PNG Gamma article of yours seems a little out of date. It's mentions browsers like Safari 2.0, IE5 Mac and Opera 7 as if they were still relevant
if you have time one day, it would be nice if you could update it to discuss the current situation
Lachy: yeah, I should probably update it to say that the article discusses a problem that has now pretty much gone away as a browser interop problem but is now relevant as a photoshop/browser problem
has a lot of outstanding feedback on the article :-(
yeah, I always had trouble getting photoshop to export PNGs in ways that played nicely with browsers
the great thing about OS X is that old releases fade into irrelevance much faster than old Windows releases
I had much more luck with Fireworks, which somehow seems to get it right
so pre-Tiger Safari doesn't matter anymore
so, is the best way to get PNGs with consistent colour to omit the colour profile information, and rely on current browsers matching the CSS colours?
Lachy: yeah. with unlabeled color for everything, CSS, bitmaps and plug-ins match
good
that would have been useful to know when I was doing web development a couple of years ago.
Lachy: you should have googled for my article!
I did read it a long time ago, but didn't really understand it too well
I just knew if I exported PNGs with Fireworks, they were right, and if I used Photoshop, they'd be wrong in some browser/platform combinations
you can use software to remove the gamma black from pngs, that's what i do anyway

I still don't really understand the concept of colour profiles too well. They seem like a hack to make poor quality hardware give good colour, instead of getting hardware vendors to produce better quality colour
most of the feedback I haven't addressed yet revolves around endorsing various removal tools
the pngcrush command the article mentions seems good enough
although, I haven't used it
Lachy: define "good colour"
i use pngthing, but i can't imagine it's any better worse than something else that does the same thing, considering
jgraham, good colour = colour that looks like what it's supposed to look like
Lachy: Define "what it's supposed to look like"
im trying to use "string".is_utf8? in my code but it gives false all the time... i dunno why it happens
sprasanna: You probably would need to give more context. But at a guess you want a more ruby-related channel
hsivonen: question about v.nu backend behavior: As far as I can see now, there's not currently a way to overwrite contents of the local-entities subdir with freshly downloaded copies, right?
MikeSmith: do you mean 3rd party ones?
hsivonen: no, I mean for the case where the contents of the upstream resource might have changed
MikeSmith: but resources that aren't in the whattf repo?
MikeSmith: I'm also curious which upstream resources have changed

hsivonen: stepping back, I'm thinking about it in the context of trying figure out the best way to handle running v.nu in "local only" .. so the upstream resources are the language-subtag-registry file, MicrosyntaxDescriptions file, Validator.nu_alt_advice file
what I want to add is some way to have the build download copies of those and store them locally
ah. there's no code for that download action right now, but build.py should have parameters that can take file URL once downloaded
hsivonen: so what I was thinking is, it'd be easiest to just use your existing entity-map.txt and downloadLocalEntities() mechanism
but -
I would want to make it possible for a user to make changes to the remote sources of those, and then re-run v.nu and incorporate those remote changes
but I think if I use the  existing entity-map.txt and downloadLocalEntities() mechanism as-is, then I can't do that
ok. perhaps there should be a build.py action for redownloading
OK, I can add that
since downloadLocalEntities() never redownloads unless you delete the local files

hsivonen: Yep. I'm just wondering if it'd be preferable to you for me to add that redownload mechanism, or just to add separate, new handling for the language-subtag-registry, MicrosyntaxDescriptions, Validator.nu_alt_advice stuff
I mean, the upstream DTDs don't change, so I suppose it's a bit of a waste to re-download them
MikeSmith: it might be best to commit microsyntax and alt advice into svn and handle languag tags like 3rd-party dtds
public-html totally needs the /topic from here to be appeneded to the end of every message
It ould make it so much easier to follow
I don't buy it that accessibility were a topic that weren't tractable to empirical research methods

hsivonen: Shell'y argument appeared to me to be "we should keep features that ere designed for accessiblity independent of their actual usefulness because their presence makes disabled people feel better even if they provide no tangible benefit"
Which seems like a pretty poor way to design a language (I would prefer to provide features that have actual benefits) not to mention rather patronising

hey, in WebStorage, it says "Multiple separate objects implementing the Storage interface can all be associated with the same list of key/value pairs simultaneously" -- http://dev.w3.org/html5/webstorage/#the-storage-interface
Is the only way that can happen when there are two pages open from the same site simultaneously, either in separate tabs or frames?

it's an aria bug that's pending input from the html wg
wonder how the html wg can provide input if html wg participants can't access the bug!
Oh well good luck on getting input if no one in the WG can see the bug :)
Oh you just said that :(
WAI should really fix their transparency issues :/
oh, where did you find the bug mentioned?
Isn't zcorpan in the wg or something?
i'm subscribed to aria-ua-impl

Hi - I'm looking for how to markup a slider in HTML5 (type="range") - but going by the documentation, I can't see anywhere where it says to use "range" as the type: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/forms.html#range-state
I was just wondering if there were docs/specs I had missed and you might be able to point me in the right direction
in http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#attr-input-type it defines how type attribute values map to states
cheers.
from a developers point of view - don't you think it might be good to have either a link to that page or a practical example implementation?
I would have found that link sooner or later,
but I'm thinking newbies to html.
that link is present from your section
type is a link
ah - from the 'type'
I think at some point Hixie will add more examples and fluff to make it more understandable
okay, not sure that's obvious, but at least it's there -
and good to hear that more examples will be added - definitely worth it for learning from.
cheers.
you can play with range in Opera/Safari fwiw
I know ;-)

needs to get an SSD for /… IO slows me down way too much.
gsnedders: More than IRC?
jgraham: Yes, I run more than just IRC :P
(This is when starting everything up after booting up, which is a side-effect of having so much open)
gsnedders: That's not what I meant :p
jgraham: Hey, I don't look at the sort of websites zcorpan does at work!
gsnedders: Why care about disk IO when you can just get lots of RAM and everything should be magically cached?
Philip`: It still has to get from IO to RAM in the first place, and that is my problem :P
gsnedders: That should happen about twice a year when you reboot your machine
Philip`: The problem is I do it closer to 52 times a year.
gsnedders: Then stop doing that :-p
gsnedders: Or stop worring about optimizing something that ony happens once a week
*worrying
doesn't think Opera is meant to do that (i.e., crash)
http://abcdefu.wordpress.com/2009/06/09/introducing-yip-an-unified-notification-system-for-the-web/
Seems prople want a standardised notification API
jgraham, it would be helpful that if you have a comment about something I write at the HTML WG mailing list, you respond to it there, instead of here
That way we have a discussion, rather than asides that pass each other in the internet night
shelleyp: Sure I was planning to, but not till this evening
jgraham: cool, thanks
I have other things to do fortunately / sadly (delete as required)
I understand, we're all overbooked
shelleyp: FWIW the comment I was planning on making is basically "I don't think that solutions that make people feel good but don't actually work should be an acceptable design goal"
(irrespective of whether @summary actually works)
jgraham: I don't want to get too far into here, I think the discussion should happen in the mailing list but...
My point was that measurements of success aren't always based on empirical observations
doesn't really understand how you can have a non-empirical measurement
Purely on semantic grounds
that YIP is basically what showNotification() in HTML5 was
(I can see logically ho you could say something like "success shouldn't be defined on empirical grounds" meaning "we won't measure anything before declaring a success or not")
grumbles about Adobe's ordering. They're saying they will cancel the order if they don't receive proof of academic identification tonight. It's was submitted over a week ago.

WFM in the past too.

jgraham: Interesting viewpoint, looking forward to reading more in your email response later tonight
jgraham, only Google was interested and wanted full HTML support
Oh

jgraham: I'm pretty sure he is too
takkaria: So I arrive after you and leave before you :P
jgraham, compelling, but it's "needed" for Workers
annevk42: Oh.
seamless sandboxed iframes are neat
especially the origin feature
hey Hixie
is there an SVN repo w/ acid3 in it somewheres?
n/m, dug it out of webkit sources...
Hixie, are we getting <iframe document> at some point before LC?
hsivonen: ping?
java.lang.ClassCastException: org.xml.sax.InputSource cannot be cast to nu.validator.xml.TypedInputSource
annevk42: depends on implementors. I don't want to add it until we have experience with sandbox.
Hmm I thought people had grasped the difference between UA requiements and author requirements, but I guess not
jgraham: I think people grasp them
they just don't think the concept is useful
it all depends on how effective you think prescriptive author requirements will be
if there were any advantage to complying with that sort of thing, websites would do it
sayrer: I think you may be projecting your view onto other people :)
well maybe, but I also want to know why they are useful
smart people seem to think they are
so I am willing to entertain the notion that I am wrong
sayrer: Generally they are useful as QA tools. If you stay within conformance you generally won't hit sharp edges that are likely to get you burnt
there is a lint aspect to them
I see that
but that is different than a conformance requirement
There is also the question of simplifying the language
hmm?
<font> is much simpler than css
for authors
By restricting the set of all working ways of achieving an effect we can focus resources on those that have the best properties for the whole ecosystem
ah, but we can't
since the spec gives quite precise requirements for everything, whether they are conformant for authors or not
that is something I fully support

sayrer: <font> doesn't scale well as a skill and tends to lead to pages that are hard to repurpose beyond the original author's intentions (e.g. to a user using a different type of UA or a screen scraper or...)
I'm not sure that's true
given the example at hand
<font color="blue">
sayrer: There is far from enough context in that example o deduce anything
well, I agree that it's possible you could do something more reusable in some situations
If you could show me that on real pages people only use <font> when they "should" have used <span>+CSS I would be more convinced
and very surprised, frankly
but a class name + a css file might also buy you an extra file and CSS
when all the author wants is a blue word
jgraham: anything syndicated generally goes for font
Oh man. That did not just happen. In a race on GTA 4, my car broke down while in the lead coming out of the final corner.
sayrer: I guess the times that "all the auhor wants is a blue word" with no context for the blueness are rather few
Compared to the cases where <font> is used
that seems quite difficult to quantify
sayrer: Sadly lots of useful things are hard to quantify in practice
sure, we don't go making MUST requirements about them :)
It is at least clear that "leading" web designers voluntarily forgo the use of <font>, suggesting that the advntages to not using it are non-theoretical
(and, I should add, they can back up their decision with cognent reasoning about mantainability and so on)
is going to try sleeping now
jgraham: they also write "xhtml"
so I think your point is questionable
night
And use floats to make table layouts
And use floats for tabular data, because tables are bad.
snicker
google.com
perhaps the most closely measured page in the history of the world
contains a font element
jaja
somebody better tell them
about their suboptimal markup
It's probably really portable!
I don't think I understand Shelley's latest email.
hober, why not?
it seems to contain a good point
which was?
you don't want to edit a font element out of a document in order to produce "conformant" markup
Who is 'you' in this case? (I think I would want to do that...)
hober, if you agree that a <span style=""> is no better
then you would want to move the CSS to a style element
that is madness
since you would be changing the "lexical scope" that a given piece of markup depends on
Well, I'd like to know why the text is blue, so I could write ..., or ...
hober, well, I don't agree that the semantics of the blue text are always worth writing down, but where do you put the styling information if it's clear that the element should be <strong>
In an external stylesheet, linked to with <link>
(ideally the selector for applying the blue style is simply "strong", too)
so you introduce a dependency like that via a wysiwyg editor?
I use Emacs to write markup. :)
hober: I take it you forfeit?
hober, but even with Emacs
are you aware of any editor that would perform that transformation?
I think the question of how to build a WYSIWYG web page editor is a separate one from what we were talking about
hober, not according to the spec
but I am willing to engage on Emacs editing modes
are there Emacs editing modes that perform the transformation you described?
What do you mean by transformation?
the author types in < s t r o n g > ...
<font color="blue"> --> <strong> + css file
the editor doesn't always create the pages it edits
The author doesn't always create the page he/she is editing, sure.
so, if I copy and thenpaste a section with <font>
should the editor paste in a font?
a font element, I mean
I mean, this is generally true of any document editing. How does an author change foo to bar in a document of type baz? Well, he/she finds all the foos and changes them to bar..
authoring tools are subject to the same requirements that authors are
If you copy source from somewhere and paste it in somewhere, I would be really annoyed if it wasn't the same source...
yes, I agree
so it will be quite impossible for authoring tools to meet the current conformance requirements
so you've got markup in an intermediate state, of unknown conformance. I don't see why it would be "quite impossible" to have a "export to conformant html5" button
with an annoying "some formatting may be lost" confirmation dialog
so it would require data loss?
lame
user writes unkown attribute or element (which are non-conformant), what does an editor replace them with?
nothing, obviously
<unknown> could become <div class="com.example.unknown">
but it might suggest something
unknown attributes though, get lost I think
a far more likely example might be
data-com-example-unknown?
hober: you could use data-com.example.attr="foo"
yeah
what you said
but if we veer into wysiwyg, this is irrelevant
it looks how it looks
... and when you click that button, and OK that dialog, the result is conformant HTML5, right?
I don't see why it wouldn't be, or rather why it can't be.
two things
I am not aware of any editor that would do that
it might be undesirable
the HTML5 standard is an astonishingly bad place to speculate on Editors Of The Future
it is sort of antithetical to the "don't mess with headers you don't understand" ethos of email
and more complicated given the external dependencies that a "proper" file would have
